docs.snippet: South America's biggest economies moved a step closer on Monday to sealing a long-sought trade deal with the European Union, a shift that could complicate efforts to forge a free trade area stretching from Alaska to Argentina by the end of the year. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: South America's biggest economies moved a step closer on Monday to sealing a long-sought trade deal with the European Union, a shift that could complicate efforts to forge a free trade area stretching from Alaska to Argentina by the end of the year. Officials from the European Union and Mercosur -- the trade bloc that includes Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay as full members, and Bolivia and Chile as associates -- exchanged offers over the weekend in Buenos Aires with an eye on closing the deal by October. The talks also managed to make progress in agriculture, a sector that has proved to be a deal breaker repeatedly in global trade talks.
docs.abstract: South America's biggest economies move step closer to sealing long-sought trade deal with European Union, shift that could complicate efforts to forge free trade area stretching fom Alaska to Argentina by end of year; officials from European Union and Mercosur--trade bloc that includes Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay as full members and Bolivia and Chile as associates--exchange offers over weekend in Buenos Aires with eye on closing deal by October; talks also manage to make progress in agriculture, sector that has proved to be deal breaker repeatedly in global trade talks; photos (L)

headline.main: Europe and South America Near Trade Accord

docs.snippet: Like most other Argentine restaurants, Hacienda de Argentina on the Upper East Side planned to serve grass-fed beef when it opened a year ago. But imports from Argentina were banned because of hoof-and-mouth disease, and the owners, Anastasios...
docs.lead_paragraph: Like most other Argentine restaurants, Hacienda de Argentina on the Upper East Side planned to serve grass-fed beef when it opened a year ago. But imports from Argentina were banned because of hoof-and-mouth disease, and the owners, Anastasios Hairatidis and Medhat Ibrahim, settled for Australian. Then something better came along. ''I found out that beef from Uruguay, right next door to Argentina, was approved,'' Mr. Hairatidis said. ''It's really the same as the beef from Argentina.'' He said his customers order Uruguayan filet mignon and strip loins twice as often as American prime. The lean Uruguayan strip loin, bottom, is a trifle chewy but it has an exceptionally beefy taste, and the flavorful filet, top, is very tender. The restaurant, at 339 East 75th Street, sells the meat by the ounce, $1.85 for the strip, $2.55 for the filet.
docs.abstract: Hacienda de Argentina on Upper East Side is serving beef from Uruguay because Argentine beef has been banned because of hoof-and-mouth disease; photo (S)

docs.snippet: A majority of Latin Americans say they would support the replacement of a democratic government with an ''authoritarian'' one if it could produce economic benefits, according to a United Nations report released Wednesday in Lima, Peru.     The...
docs.lead_paragraph: A majority of Latin Americans say they would support the replacement of a democratic government with an ''authoritarian'' one if it could produce economic benefits, according to a United Nations report released Wednesday in Lima, Peru. The report, a harsh self-analysis compiled by Latin Americans, says that the region, which has succeeded in freeing itself from a long history of military coups and dictatorships, is facing a new challenge to democratic rule because of popular disenchantment with its elected governments.
docs.abstract: United Nations report states that majority of Latin Americans say they would support replacement of democratic government with 'authoritarian' one if it could produce economic benefits; harsh self-analysis compiled by Latin Americans says region, finally freed from long history of military coups and dictatorships, faces new challenge to democratic rule because of popular disenchantment with its elected governments; notes voter turnout is falling across region, especially among young, while civil unrest is on rise; report looked at 18 nations, conducted opinion surveys of over 18,000 citizens and lengthy interviews with 231 political, economic, social and cultural figures (M)

headline.main: Latin America Losing Hope In Democracy, Report Says

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT

docs.snippet: Achieving a free trade agreement with the United States was supposed to be the magic moment that certified Chile's entry into the elite club of stable, democratic and prosperous nations. Instead, the new accord, signed in January, has reignited a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Achieving a free trade agreement with the United States was supposed to be the magic moment that certified Chile's entry into the elite club of stable, democratic and prosperous nations. Instead, the new accord, signed in January, has reignited a sometimes anguished debate here about what it means to be Latin American and whether Chile has somehow lost those essential characteristics. Since the beginning of the decade, all three of Chile's neighbors have suffered political and economic convulsions that have forced changes of government. In sharp contrast to Argentina, Bolivia and Peru, not to mention the rest of South America, Chile these days looks ''dull but virtuous,'' to borrow the title of a recent report by one Wall Street brokerage house.
docs.abstract: Chile's new free trade agreement with US, intended to certify entry into elite club of stable, democratic, prosperous nations, reignites debate on whether country is somehow losing its Latin American identity; country where most people pay their taxes, laws are rigidly enforced and police only rarely seek bribes is curiously unpopular in region with few such virtues; photos (M)

headline.main: Chile, the Rich Kid on the Block (It Starts to Feel Lonely)

docs.snippet: Planning for national elections in Iraq is ahead of schedule, but violence must decline for the United Nations to oversee them, the chief of the organization's electoral assistance division said Monday.    ''If security does not improve, the U.N....
docs.lead_paragraph: Planning for national elections in Iraq is ahead of schedule, but violence must decline for the United Nations to oversee them, the chief of the organization's electoral assistance division said Monday. ''If security does not improve, the U.N. won't participate in elections,'' said the official, Carina Perelli.
docs.abstract: United Nations electoral assistance official Carina Perelli says planning for national elections in Iraq is ahead of schedule, but violence must decline for UN to oversee them; acknowledges there has been deterioration in security since she began her mission to Baghdad this year; estimates $260 million has been set aside to pay for voting, scheduled for Jan 2005 (M)

headline.main: U.N.'s Plans to Oversee Voting in Iraq Hinge on Drop in Violence

docs.snippet: It began with Brazil's soybean farmers.    Pedro de Camargo Neto, then a top official of the Brazilian Rural Society, Brazil's most influential agriculture lobby, kept hearing complaints in the late 1990's from farmers that, just as they were...
docs.lead_paragraph: It began with Brazil's soybean farmers. Pedro de Camargo Neto, then a top official of the Brazilian Rural Society, Brazil's most influential agriculture lobby, kept hearing complaints in the late 1990's from farmers that, just as they were starting to turn a profit with their soybean exports, they were getting clobbered by lower-priced American soybeans that were heavily subsidized with taxpayers' money. ''Something was wrong here,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''I didn't understand how this could be happening.''
docs.abstract: Article on recent World Trade Organization's preliminary ruling favoring Brazil over US on US subsidies for cotton farmers; focuses on efforts of Pedro de Camargo Neto, former Brazilian agiculture official, that led to victory; WTO ruled that multi-billion-dollar subsidies to biggest American cotton farmers and agribusinesses amounted to unfair trading practices; photo (M)

headline.main: Brazil's Road to Victory Over U.S. Cotton

byline.original: By ELIZABETH BECKER and TODD BENSON; Elizabeth Becker reported for this article from Washington and Todd Benson from São Paulo

docs.snippet: The Senate blocked legislation that would have made Uruguay the first country to legalize abortion in Latin America. The bill had been approved in the lower house in December 2002. The national Doctors Union says that 30,000 to 50,000 illegal...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate blocked legislation that would have made Uruguay the first country to legalize abortion in Latin America. The bill had been approved in the lower house in December 2002. The national Doctors Union says that 30,000 to 50,000 illegal abortions are carried out each year in Uruguay, a country with a population of 3.5 million and 52,000 births annually.
docs.abstract: Uruguay, which passed legislation in lower house to legalize abortion in December 2002, has bill blocked by Senate; would have been first Latin American country to legalize abortion (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Abortion Bill Rejected

docs.snippet: The awful truth is that life in this ruined patch of Haiti may be better now than it has ever been, or will ever be again.    Doctors and nurses treated the sick and wounded on Sunday in a shack that passed for a clinic. Hulking American helicopters...
docs.lead_paragraph: The awful truth is that life in this ruined patch of Haiti may be better now than it has ever been, or will ever be again. Doctors and nurses treated the sick and wounded on Sunday in a shack that passed for a clinic. Hulking American helicopters delivered tons of food. People with money and power -- aid workers and American soldiers -- attended to Mapou.
docs.abstract: Aid workers and US soldiers in Haiti bring food and medical treatment to Mapou but military's departure will leave huge gap in desperately poor community where people say no Haitian leader has ever come; photos; map; Haitian government has only about $3 per person to help estimated 75,000 people affected by recent floods (M)

headline.main: A Haitian Village Gets a Barrage of Care

docs.snippet: United States commanders began turning over this anarchic, flood-ravaged, starving nation 500 miles from Florida to a handful of United Nations troops on Tuesday.    The 3,600-member American-led military force brought a measure of stability to Haiti...
docs.lead_paragraph: United States commanders began turning over this anarchic, flood-ravaged, starving nation 500 miles from Florida to a handful of United Nations troops on Tuesday. The 3,600-member American-led military force brought a measure of stability to Haiti after the first Marines landed Feb. 29, the day President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was forced from power under rebel attack and American pressure.
docs.abstract: United States military commanders begin turning over Haiti to United Nations contingent that will try to lead anarchic nation toward elections; photos (M)

headline.main: U.S. Begins Transfer of a Shaky Haiti to U.N. Hands

docs.snippet: In his first public address, Iraq's new prime minister on Friday defended the presence of American and British forces on Iraqi soil and warned that their departure would be a catastrophe for the country.    Iyad Allawi, speaking on television three...
docs.lead_paragraph: In his first public address, Iraq's new prime minister on Friday defended the presence of American and British forces on Iraqi soil and warned that their departure would be a catastrophe for the country. Iyad Allawi, speaking on television three days after being chosen prime minister, said his compatriots, ''as Iraqis, can never accept occupation,'' and he vowed to reclaim the country's full sovereignty on June 30.
docs.abstract: Prime Min Iyad Allawi, in his first public address, defends presence of US and British forces on Iraqi soil and warns that their departure would be catastrophe for country; United Nations officials say they will devise system of proportional representation to elect members for 275-member national assembly in vote scheduled for Jan 2005; photo (M)

headline.main: U.S. Troops Needed, Iraq's New Premier Says
headline.kicker: THE REACH OF WAR: ADDRESS TO IRAQIS

byline.original: By DEXTER FILKINS; Warren Hoge contributed reporting from the United Nations for this article
